questions.question: Why is tea the most popular drink after water? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: It is refreshing, aromatic and widely enjoyed around the world.

questions.answer: Camellia sinensis.

questions.question: What are flushes? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: New buds and top young leaves plucked for processing.

questions.question: Name the three tea‑growing regions in India. (Variant 54)
questions.answer: Darjeeling, Assam and Nilgiris.

questions.answer: Because plants grow slowly and develop a better flavour.

questions.question: Explain how tea is grown, harvested and processed before it reaches us. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: Tea grows on Camellia sinensis shrubs in warm, rainy climates. Young leaves called flushes are plucked, then dried and processed into different types before being packed and sold.

questions.question: Describe the legends that explain how tea was first discovered. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: One legend tells how Emperor Shennong tasted water infused by accident with leaves; another tells how Bodhidharma used tea to stay awake while meditating.

questions.question: How did tea spread beyond China to become a world drink? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Buddhist monks, travellers, traders and later the British helped tea seeds, culture and plantations travel to Japan, Russia, Europe and India.

questions.question: Explain the medicinal and health benefits of tea mentioned in the passage. (Insight 154)
questions.answer: Tea contains caffeine and theanine, making it stimulating, and flavonoid antioxidants that may protect against disease and improve health.

questions.question: Why is tea a social and cultural drink in many parts of the world? (Insight 155)
questions.answer: Tea is shared with guests, used in ceremonies, and enjoyed in groups. In Japan, China and Korea it has cultural rituals, while in India it is offered as hospitality.
